title: Is this third party program legal to use?

embed.description: Free, Easy Install... 1. Download and install Overwolf from http://www.Overwolf.com 2. Launch Overwolf and click on the Appstore icon. 3. Search for "lolwiz" on the upper right then click INSTALL! Overwolf Appstore Home Page: http://www.overwolf.com/apps/tsgw2_contest/#!appId=dmpfhbhjknfmncjinjaikncjjnklcplnodamiimn LoLwiz is a FREE app optimized for Overwolf which provides an enhanced loading screen + in game stats showing rank, KDA, masteries, and wins/losses for each summoner.

body: I've heard a while ago about a Rioter saying that "nothing should interfere with the game experience from "Play" to the end of game results screen" when it comes to third party programs. While I have seen that being used as an argument against functionality about information you normally shouldn't see (I've once seen a program that lets you see what champions are being picked by your opponents in blind pick normals and in ARAMs during champion select), I'm not 100% sure about information that can be retrieved using legal thrid party sites such as lolnexus.com and lolking.net; I would really like a detailed explanation about what EXACTLY is and isn't allowed to be used in third party applications.

replies.body:
Personally, I've never really been satisfied with their definition of "interference with the gameplay experience," or lack thereof, really.  Obviously any bot that plays the game for you or program that gives you vision of things you shouldn't be able to see is bad, but fundamentally, this program does change the gameplay experience... that is to say, it makes it better (provided that their code doesn't crash).

Things like that don't give you inappropriate knowledge of the game (you could look up all the champion/summoner statistics if you really wanted to, it's just inconvenient) and IMO ought to be fine.  That said, Riot's vague policy catches things like this in the crossfire.  They're probably intentionally vague because it's hard to nail down what is and isn't reasonable except on a case-by-case basis.  I certainly can't think of a better way to word their policy that doesn't catch reasonable programs in the crossfire.
